(in the Marche region) and employs just under 5,000 inhabitants. Cupramontana is the capital of "Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi", one of the main Italian white wines and the birthplace of Luigi Bartolini, great engraver of the twentieth century and author of the novel "Ladri di biciclette". Located in the heart of the Marche region, 505 meters above sea level, is Cupramontana the ideal place for a green holiday, for "wine and food" tours and cultural tourism.

Ancient olive trees, vineyards and breathtaking hillside surround Cupramontana, the capital of the Verdicchio. At the highest point of the historic city, located ca.550 m high, one looks west over the mountains of the Apennines and the eastern Adriatic Sea.

The frazione Poggio Cupro is part of the municipality.

Cupramontana, in the middleages until 1861 called Massaccio, got its name from the goddess Cupra, goddess of fertility and love. On this territory was brought to live a civilisation of traditional life and cultivation of the soil. During the greek-gotic battle in the VI century, the old roman village Cupramontana was completely destroyed and forgotten for ages. It were first the benedict monks and afterwards between the VIII and XI century the camaldolesian monks, who reintroduced the cultivation of vineyards. The viniculture would increase over the years and already in the 16th century you could find vineyards growing together with fieldmaple (acer campestris), a technique until recently in use.
In the 18th century they even got an overproduction, so they started exportation to other regions.
From then on, the Verdicchio grape, which grew perfectly in the local hilly soil and microclimate, became the most used grape in the area.

Part of Cupramontana, completely surrounded by medieval walls and restored in the early sixteenth century. Above the arched entrance of the castle there is the fresco "Madonna and Child" (1529), attributed to Pier Paolo Agabiti (1470-1540). The church of S. Redeemer from the XII century, together with the castle, was rebuilt in the late fifteenth century. The portal is from 1516 and the fresco of San Floriano, discovered in 1965, is the oldest image of the patron saint of Jesi. The church also contains a painted wooden statue from the first half of the XVI century.

, late July. The tradition of folk dancing still lives in this city. The Saltarello is the main dance and in honor of folklore an annual international festival of folklore is held.

, first Saturday of September. In the old castle of Poggio Cupro, a hamlet that has maintained its historic appearance, there is the medieval evening. Tourists and residents in medieval costumes, take part together at a dinner and taste the medieval tradition, attending performances, art demonstrations and parades in medieval style.

, first weekend of October. Every first weekend of October, Italy's second oldest "Festa dell'Uva" takes place in Cupramontana. It is the celebration of the grape and Verdichhio wine. It is a four-day festival of people, performances, shows and local dishes. Annually, more than 40,000 visitors take part in this event. The floats in the parade on Sunday, adorned with grapes, is the highlight.

The city is known for its delicious white wine Verdicchio. All winemakers invite you to tastings and proudly display their conventional or organic production. Even the excellent olive oil in the area, you can test and experiment in local olive oil mills.

is an association, founded in 2003, which provides accommodation in the Marche to promote tourism in the area of Cupramontana, capital of the Verdicchio.
The association consists of touristic structures operating on the principles of green accommodation and rural hospitality; bed & breakfasts, agriturism, country houses and apartments.
This type of hospitality means a lot of human contact, strong ties with the land, regional traditions, the inherent cultural richness, local products and the eno-gastronomia. All members of the association promote rural economy, integrating this with a strong sense of rural hospitality.
A lot of them are also working farming businesses.
